In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The telecoms market in the Pacific is dominated by high tariffs, low access rates, and 
low participation by the private sector. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been involved 
in several recent projects to address these issues. In 2009, ADB provided a corporate loan to 
Digicel to support the expansion of its mobile telecoms network in Papua New Guinea.1 In 2011, 
ADB extended a $40 million project loan and made an $8 million equity investment to support 
the Bemobile Expansion Project in both Papua New Guinea and Solomon Islands.2 Together, 
these projects will increase the penetration of high-quality, affordable mobile telecom services in 
both countries. 
 
2.  Network  expansion  in  Solomon  Islands  is  challenging  owing  to  the  geographic 
dispersion of the population, difficult geography, and lack of existing power sector infrastructure. 
To maximize the success of the Bemobile Expansion Project and to ensure that new network 
assets are deployed in an efficient, sustainable, and socially responsible manner, Bemobile has 
requested technical assistance (TA) to pilot test renewable energy technologies in support of 
mobile base stations in Solomon Islands. The TA will support Bemobile to demonstrate the 
extent to which renewable technologies can reduce reliance on costly diesel power generation, 
and it will pilot community power business models and investigate other methods for increasing 
the social inclusiveness of the Bemobile Expansion Project. Lessons learned will be shared with 
other market participants, and technical findings and resource assessments will be used to 
scale up the use of renewable energy technologies by telecoms operators throughout Solomon 
Islands. The TA will provide a template for replication across the Pacific. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Solomon Islands is one of the poorest countries in the region, with annual per capita 
income of $1,256 in 2009.3 The population is highly fragmented and communities are confined 
to islands distanced by sea and difficult terrain. Some 80% of the population lives in small and 
dispersed  settlements,  many  of  which  are  remote.  Communication  is  challenging  and 
contributes to low employment, few income-generating opportunities, and poor access to basic 
services. 
 
4.  The  telecoms  market  in  Solomon  Islands  is  characterized  by  high  tariffs  and  low 
penetration rates and was negatively impacted in 2000 when many facilities were destroyed 
during civil unrest. Consequently, Solomon Islands is one of the least ―connected‖ countries in 
the world. Most areas have no access to communications infrastructure—in 2008, the fixed line 
penetration rate was 1.6% while mobile penetration was 6.0%.4 Tariffs are high relative to 
regional comparators and per capita incomes. Although the cost of local mobile calls has fallen, 
it  is  still  over  $0.20  per  minute.  Voice-over-internet-protocol  calls  are  very  expensive  and 
broadband access is limited to the capital, Honiara. 
 
5.  Steps have been taken to improve penetration rates and tariff levels. Since 2008, the 
government  has  begun  to  introduce  competition  and  transfer  regulatory  functions  to  an 
independent body. The monopoly status of Our Telekom was renegotiated and a new operator,

Bemobile, was awarded a concession and launched operations in 2010. Although subscriber 
growth increased markedly from 5,000 in August 2010 to about 60,000 in December 2010, 
significant investment in network expansion is required to increase penetration rates and reduce 
tariff levels. 
 
6.  ADB is helping to address these issues with the Bemobile Expansion Project. Through a 
$40 million loan and a $9 million equity investment, ADB is supporting Bemobile to increase the 
penetration of high-quality, affordable mobile telecom services in Solomon Islands. The project 
will expand the Bemobile network and improve the accessibility and quality of telecom service, 
particularly in remote and low-income areas. The improved network will enable better access to 
information, including for public service delivery, education, health, and security. Increased 
affordability and accessibility will enable inclusive economic growth by facilitating access to 
markets and developing other businesses relying on telecoms services. The project will support 
the government strategy of encouraging private sector participation, which is critical given the 
level of investment required and limited self-financing capacity. 
 
7.  Despite these efforts, barriers to the efficiency and sustainability of network expansion 
remain. In particular, the availability of grid power in Solomon Islands is extremely limited. Less 
than 20% of all households have access to electricity and about 80% of all electricity is supplied 
to Honiara. Most mobile base station equipment is supplied by on-site diesel generators. These 
are costly to run and involve complex logistical arrangements to ensure sufficient diesel is on 
hand. Reliance on diesel emits carbon dioxide and causes local environmental pollution, and 
the provision of power to mobile base stations currently accounts for more than half of all 
network operation costs. 
 
8.  Renewable and remote monitoring technologies offer the opportunity to reduce the cost 
of  operating  mobile  networks,  and  improve  the  environmental  sustainability  and  quality  of 
telecoms services in remote locations. Although renewable technologies can be commercially 
viable, few pilot projects exist in the Pacific and diesel power remains the baseline technology.5 
Widespread  deployment  in  Solomon  Islands  requires  assistance  in  the  form  of  resource 
assessment, technology selection, training, and capacity building. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will support mobile operators in Solomon Islands to increase the penetration of 
high-quality,  affordable  mobile  telecom  services  in  an  efficient,  sustainable,  and  socially 
responsible manner. The TA will (i) carry out a solar and wind resource assessment for mobile 
base stations; (ii) pilot test solar, wind, and remote monitoring technologies in at least two base 
stations;  (iii)  provide  training  in  operation  and  maintenance  and  best  practice  engineering 
(e.g., limited land clearance, slope protection, erosion control) in relation to these renewable 
energy technologies; (iv) pilot test community power models and identify follow-on schemes to 
increase community access to power; and (v) prepare specifications for scaling up the number 
of mobile base stations powered by solar and wind technologies. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be the increased penetration in Solomon Islands of high-
quality, affordable mobile telecom services provided in an efficient, sustainable, and socially 
responsible manner. Performance targets and indicators include (i) an increase in the mobile 
                                                
5 GSM Association. 2009. Green Power for Mobile Programme Digicel Vanuatu. London.

3 
penetration rate in Solomon Islands from 6% in 2008 to 35% by 2015; and (ii) a 50% reduction 
in fuel costs for mobile base stations by 2015 from the 2010 baseline of $1.5 million. The 
outcome of the TA will be that mobile operators reduce reliance on diesel for power generation 
at mobile base station locations. Performance targets and indicators include  the following: 
(i) pilot projects reduce diesel consumption by 44,000 liters and carbon dioxide emissions by 
96 tons per year by 2013; and (ii) follow-on projects identified that reduce diesel consumption by 
1.5 million liters and carbon emissions by 3,400 tons per year at 70 base stations by 2013. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will be structured around five outputs as follows: (i) a solar and wind resource 
assessment for mobile base stations is undertaken; (ii) solar, wind, and remote monitoring 
technologies  are  pilot  tested;  (iii)  training  in  operation  and maintenance  and  best  practice 
engineering in relation to these renewable energy technologies is provided; (iv) community 
power models are pilot tested and follow-on schemes to increase community access to power 
are identified; and (v) technical specifications for future base stations to be powered by solar 
and wind technologies are prepared. 
 
12.  Risks to the success of the TA include (i) regulatory uncertainty as a result of ongoing 
legislative change; (ii) delay or cancellation of planned network expansion activities of mobile 
operators in Solomon Islands; and (iii) deterioration of the business environment. These risks 
are addressed through ADB’s deep involvement in the telecoms sector in Solomon Islands 
through the  Bemobile Expansion  Project  and thorough  consultation  during TA  preparation. 
Procurement risks will be mitigated by outsourcing this activity to the TA consulting firm and by 
sound application of ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Social and environmental concerns will be addressed by ensuring TA compliance with ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  safeguard  provisions  in  the  Bemobile  Expansion 
Project. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). Bemobile will provide in-
kind contributions to finance the cost of counterpart staff, office accommodation, communication, 
and local transport. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over an 18-month period commencing 1 January 2012 and 
ending 30 June 2013. Bemobile, the only private sector mobile operator in Solomon Islands, will 
serve as the executing agency and will be responsible for in-country execution of the TA. ADB, 
through the user division, Private Sector Infrastructure Finance Division 2, will be responsible for 
recruitment  of  consulting  services,  negotiating  the  consulting  contract,  and  supervising 
(including  billing  and  payment)  the  consulting  services  during  implementation.  A  letter 
agreement  has  been  implemented  with  the  executing  agency  setting  out  the  terms  and 
conditions of the TA. The Private Sector Infrastructure Finance Division 2 and the executing 
agency will each assign a project officer who will be responsible for (i) timely communication 
and actions between the consulting firm, the executing agency, and ADB; (ii) monitoring and 
when appropriate providing guidance to the consulting firm; (iii) attending scheduled review 
meetings at the start, middle, and end of the TA; and (iv) reviewing, commenting on, and 
approving the inception and final reports.

4   
 
15.  The TA will require an estimated 10.5 person-months of international consulting services 
and 5.5 person-months of national consulting services. The terms of reference are outlined in 
Appendix 3. Consulting services will be provided through a firm and will be recruited using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method at a ratio of 90:10. The firm will be engaged in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time) and will be selected using the simplified technical proposal method. 
 
16.  The consulting firm will be responsible for the procurement of equipment for the pilot 
projects and will undertake this activity in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. 
Installation and commissioning will be carried out by the equipment supplier; the TA consulting 
firm will supervise these activities and test the equipment to ensure its satisfactory operation. 
Upon  completion,  ownership  of  equipment  will  pass  to  the  executing  agency  and  a 
memorandum of understanding covering its operation will be agreed. The proceeds of the TA 
will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Outputs of the TA will be disseminated through using 
knowledge products and in-country workshops. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
Bemobile Limited for Renewable Energy for Telecom Networks, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

B.  Consultant Inputs 
 
9.  Mobile telecoms specialist and team leader (international, 3 person-months). The 
telecoms specialist and team leader will have a minimum of 10 years demonstrated experience 
in the design and implementation of mobile base station infrastructure. The specialist will have 
experience  of  working  in  developing  countries  in  remote  locations,  preferably  with  prior 
experience  of  the  Pacific  region.  The  specialist  will  act  as  team  leader  and  take  overall 
responsibility for managing and coordinating the TA. Individual tasks will include, but not be 
limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Review background reports, legislation, and regulatory documentation relating to 
the telecoms sector in Solomon Islands. 
(ii)  Undertake  meetings  with  stakeholders  from  government  and  nongovernment 
agencies as necessary. 
(iii)  Conduct  meetings  with  Bemobile  staff,  and  understand  the  structure  and 
configuration of existing and planned telecoms infrastructure. Review activities 
relating to the operation of existing mobile base stations and understand the 
technical, financial, and management implications. 
(iv)  Oversee  activities  of  the  renewable  energy  engineers  to  identify  suitable 
renewable energy technologies applicable to mobile base station operation in 
Solomon Islands, and manage the assessment of solar and wind resources in 
areas of future planned network expansion.

(xi)  Take responsibility for the preparation of the inception and final reports, and work 
with the other specialists to summarize good practice and lessons learned in a 
knowledge  product.  Conduct  a  final  workshop  to  disseminate  knowledge 
throughout the Pacific region. 
 
10.  Renewable energy engineers (international, 3 person-months; and national, 3 person-
months). The international renewable energy engineer will be a qualified electrical engineer and 
have a minimum of 8 years demonstrated experience in the design and implementation of 
small-scale off-grid renewable energy systems in support of mobile base station infrastructure. 
The specialist will have experience of working in developing countries in remote locations. The 
national renewable energy engineer will have a minimum of 5 years demonstrated experience in 
the power sector, preferably with experience of small-scale off-grid renewable energy systems 
in Solomon Islands. Individual tasks will include, but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Survey the existing mobile base station infrastructure of Bemobile in Solomon 
Islands and review technical aspects of expansion plans. 
(ii)  Conduct  a  study  of  energy  demand  requirements  of  telecoms  infrastructure; 
analyze fuel usage and existing load profile using appropriate software. 
(iii)  Identify suitable renewable energy technologies applicable to mobile base station 
operation,  and  assess  solar  and  wind  resources  in  areas  of  future  planned 
network expansion using NASA and 3-TIER datasets. Work with Bemobile to

projects, and evaluate success in the final report. 
(vi)  Draft  training  manual  for  operation  and  maintenance  and  best  practice 
engineering (e.g. limited land clearance, slope protection, erosion control) for 
renewably powered mobile base stations, and conduct classroom and on-site 
training for technicians of mobile operators. 
(vii)  Review  expansion  plans  of  Bemobile,  and  prepare  design  specifications  for 
renewable and energy-efficient technology solutions for the 70 new mobile base 
stations. 
(viii)  Review policies and plans relating to future expansion of the power sector and 
ensure the expansion proposals are consistent with future development of the 
grid. 
(ix)  Work with the social specialists to identify and determine technical specifications 
for at least five additional schemes for expanding community access to power, 
using base stations to be implemented under the Bemobile Expansion Project. 
(x)  Contribute to relevant sections of the inception and final reports. 
(xi)  Assist the team leader in drafting all deliverables. 
 
11.  Energy economist (international, 2 person-months). The energy economist will have a 
minimum  of  8  years  demonstrated  experience  in  economic  and  financial  appraisal  of 
infrastructure projects, especially of telecoms and renewable energy projects. The specialist will 
have experience of working in developing countries in remote locations. Individual tasks will 
include, but not be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  Review background reports, legislation, and regulatory documentation relating to 
the telecoms sector in Solomon Islands. 
(ii)  Understand  business  activities  of  Bemobile  and  review  annual  reports, 
management accounts, and future business plans. 
(iii)  Work with the renewable energy engineers to prepare cost estimates for the pilot 
projects.  Carry  out  in-depth  financial  analysis,  including  calculation  of  the 
financial internal rate of return, payback period, and unit cost of electricity from 
the pilot solar and wind projects. Compare the cost of renewable pilot projects 
with the cost of electricity from diesel generators at each mobile base station. 
Ensure all calculations are carried out in accordance with ADB guidelines. 
(iv)  Extrapolate results across the network and calculate the financial implications of 
switching to renewable energy technologies for each operator. 
(v)  Incorporate findings into the business plans of Bemobile and conduct sensitivity 
analysis. 
(vi)  Prepare  cost  estimates  for  output  5  and  quantify  the  financial  impact  of 
implementing renewable energy solutions at the 70 new mobile base stations. 
(vii)  Work with the team leader and social specialists to develop a financial model for 
the community power pilot project, assess willingness to pay for power services

Appendix 3  13 
by local communities, and assess the costs associated with the five additional 
schemes for expanding access to power. 
(viii)  Prepare summary financial analysis suitable for inclusion in knowledge product 
for widespread dissemination. 
(ix)  Assess the potential of the pilot projects and follow-on activities to attract carbon 
financing  through  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism.  Calculate  expected 
emission reductions and consider a programmatic approach to carbon financing. 
Draft a program of activities if necessary. 
 
12.  Social specialists (international, 2.5 person-months; and national, 2.5 person-months). 
The international specialist will have at least 10 years experience and the national specialist will 
have at least 5 years experience in social analysis of infrastructure projects. They will have 
experience  of  stakeholder  consultation  and  will  have  implemented  small-scale  community 
energy projects in the past. The consultants’ work will consist of the following: 
 
(i)  Collect  available  reports  and  published  statistics  that  are  relevant  to  the  TA, 
including previous examples of community power projects associated with mobile 
base stations. 
(ii)  Identify different models of community engagement including handset charging, 
community micro-grids, and other micro-enterprises. 
(iii)  Work  with  Bemobile  and  screen  and  select  suitable  mobile  base  stations  for 
implementation of the pilot community power initiatives. 
(iv)  Identify the TA stakeholders and examine their existing rights and possible risks 
from the initiative. 
(v)  Working closely with the executing agency, organize and conduct surveys in the 
project area, and consult with government and nongovernment organizations to 
supplement secondary data. Prepare a poverty profile of the pilot project area. 
(vi)  Conduct stakeholder consultation activities, as necessary, taking care to ensure 
that community groups are well represented, not only by the community leaders 
but also by the poor, elderly, disabled, and women, so that marginal peoples’ 
voices are heard and not captured by the local elites. 
(vii)  Assess  the  willingness-to-pay  and  pro-poor  impacts  of  the  project,  taking  into 
account linkage effects; and assess the capacity of the poor to pay for electricity 
services. 
(viii)  Develop a detailed design for the pilot projects based on consultation findings; and 
oversee pilot project development, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation. 
(ix)  Work with the team leader to prepare material for a basic workshop on household 
budgeting  for  electricity  use,  and  present  at  workshops  during  project 
implementation. 
(x)  Review  the  Bemobile  Expansion  Project  and  identify  at  least  five  future  base 
stations that are suitable for expanding community access to power. Assess the 
feasibility of these schemes and prepare an indicative project design.
